bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1948

div1.p: Siler discusses the location of the room where Walter Reed died. Siler knows that Hench wants to check on information contained in Hagedorn's biography of Wood and promises to arrange a meeting with McCoy.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1948
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
February 10, 1948
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I am just in receipt of a letter from General Truby relative to the location of
the room in the hospital at Washington Barracks in which Walter Reed died. He had
received the plans showing the location of the room insofar as could be determined from
the present layout. He apparently thinks the exact location of the room has not yet
been worked out and should be gone into more fully. As requested by him, I am sending
you a copy of the letter he has written me concerning this matter. I am also to send
copies to the Commanding Officer at Ft. McNair, Gen. Kean and Gen. Lawrence Reed.

Truby advises me that you will be in Washington next week and I am holding up the
copies which are to be sent to the CO at Ft. McNair, Gen. Kean and Gen. Lawrence Reed
until after your arrival here and we have had a chance to discuss the matter a bit.

The letter referred to above was dated February 4th and in the same mail yesterday
I received an air mail letter from Gen. Truby under date of February 7th in which he en-
closed a copy of your letter of January 9th written to Gen. Kean. Gen. Truby has incor-
porated a number of comments on the copy of your letter to Gen. Kean which I will show you
on your arrival in Washington next week. Your letter of Gen. Kean relates to the question
of Major Reed's being transferred from Havana before his work could be completed and the
steps taken by Gen. Wood to have him remain in Cuba to complete his work. I gather from
your letter that you desire to check on this information and other information contained
in Hagedorn's biography of Gen. Leonard Wood and that you feel that it might be possible
to secure additional trustworthy information from Gen. McCoy. Gen. Truby asked me to look
into the matter and find out where Gen. McCoy is living and whether it would be possible
for you to get in touch with him.

Fortunately, Gen. McCoy lives here in Washington. He is connected with the State
Department in the Far Eastern Commission. I talked to him by telephone last night and
told him of your desire to consult him concerning this matter. He assured me that he
would be glad to see you although he said his memory now is a bit hazy since, of course,
all these things happened forty or fifty years ago. Gen. McCoy lives out in Georgetown
but has an office in the old Japanese Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue. I have made a
tentative appointment for him to see you when you are in Washington next week. He said
that it would be very much more convenient for him to see you during the week between
Monday and Friday, except on Tuesday and Thursday on which days he has special confer-
ences which he must attend. I have known Gen. McCoy for a great many years and served
with him in the Philippines when I was a member of the commission stuying the means
of the transmission of dengue fever when Gen. Wood was Governor General. He is a fine
character and I know that he will be delighted to give you any help within his power.

GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED

1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.

We have been having terrible weather here in Washington and it has been very dif-
ficult to get around. On top of that I am just recovering from a cold. I am hoping
that the snow will be gone and that I will be able to see you next week.

As soon as the weather clears up a bit more, I will go and see Gen. Kean and show
him all these letters from Truby.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, J. F. Siler
Col. U.S.A., Retired jfs k
